awd_abstract_narration:
Polynomial optimization is a fundamental computational technique, with applications in a wide variety of fields that include power systems engineering, signal processing, statistics, geometry, and medicine. There are several existing computational approaches for polynomial optimization; however, they all share a few core ideas that limit both their efficiency and stability. As the size and complexity of the models arising from modern applications continues to increase, these existing approaches are increasingly limiting. This research project is aimed toward the development of novel computational methods that are simultaneously more reliable and more efficient than the existing techniques. To assure the relevance of the research, the approaches will be implemented as easily usable computational tools, which will be disseminated widely to the scientific and engineering community.

One of the most common approaches to the solution of global polynomial optimization problems utilizes semi-definite programming (SDP) hierarchies. These arise from combining the algebraic theory of sum-of-squares polynomials and the observation that sum-of-squares polynomials are semi-definite representable. While theoretically satisfactory, the translation of sum-of-squares optimization problems to SDPs is not always practical. First, the SDP representation of sum-of-squares polynomials roughly squares the number of optimization variables, increasing the time and memory complexity of the solution algorithms by several orders of magnitude. The second problem is numerical. In the common SDP formulation, the dual variables are semi-definite matrices whose condition numbers grow exponentially with the degree of the polynomials involved. This is detrimental for a floating-point implementation. This project builds on recent results in non-symmetric conic optimization and multivariate interpolation to derive the algorithmic theory and practical computational tools needed to circumvent the need to use the standard SDP-based approach to sum-of-squares optimization. The aim is to provide algorithms for these problems that are both efficient and computationally effective. The principal investigator will investigate the impact of the novel algorithm developments for a diverse set of applications, including the design of optimal radiotherapy treatments.

por.por_cntn:
Polynomial optimization is a fundamental computational technique, with applications in a wide variety of fields that include medicine, power systems engineering, signal processing, statistics, and geometry. There are several existing computational approaches for polynomial optimization; however, they all share a few core ideas that limit both their efficiency and stability. As the size and complexity of the models arising from modern applications continues to increase, existing approaches are increasingly limiting. This research project was aimed toward the development of novel computational methods that are simultaneously more reliable and more efficient than the existing techniques. To assure the relevance of the research, the developed methods were implemented as easily usable computational tools, disseminated widely to the scientific and engineering community, and applied within the PI’s medical collaboration.

The project’s outcomes in numbers. The research has led to 1 PhD dissertation (in Applied Mathematics) with 1 more (in Mathematics) in progress; 9 completed scientific papers, 6 of which have already been published (others are under review) in leading mathematical and medical journals. Additional publications are under preparation. The mathematical results were presented by the PI and his students in 12 conferences and seminars, with additional talks scheduled for later this year and the next. Furthermore, an open-source software codenamed alfonso has been released.

Mathematical contributions. The primary theoretical breakthrough of the project is a novel approach to the solution of sum-of-squares optimization problems, which is perhaps the most common building block in modern polynomial optimization methods. The new technique leads to an improvement of three orders of magnitude in running time even for univariate polynomials, both in theory and in practice. This has the potential to completely replace the conventional approach of solving sum-of-squares optimization problems using semidefinite programming.

The numerical optimization component of the technique was also broadly generalized, resulting in a general-purpose non-symmetric cone programming method; this method was implemented in the open-source Matlab package alfonso. Unlike optimization over symmetric cones (linear, second-order cone, and semidefinite programming), non-symmetric cone programming has minimal algorithmic support and virtually no reliable software available to the community. Alfonso is one of the first open-source optimization software that can tackle optimization problems at this level of generality. Among other applications, the algorithm (and code) were used in another novel approach to computing certified lower bounds on polynomials, using nonnegative circuit polynomials.

Applications in medicine and other outcomes. The PI’s collaboration with research hospitals on radiotherapy optimization has provided several very large scale and challenging optimization problems. These arise, for example, in the context of the optimal fractionation and in the context of multi-modality radiation therapy. The former is concerned with the question of how to optimally deliver treatments over a series of treatment sessions, while the latter is concerned with combining conventional photon radiotherapy with the far less available (and far more costly) but generally superior proton therapy to maximize the benefit of individual patients as well as the entire patient cohort. These treatment modality concepts lead to optimization problems far more challenging than conventional radiotherapy optimization, therefore it was not even clear at the outset how to compute optimal treatments of these types. The tools developed in this project helped establish the computational feasibility of these treatment techniques and was used to quantify the potential benefit of patients who receive these novel treatments over conventional treatments.

Underscoring the potential impact of this research on the future of radiation therapy, one of the publications from this project was selected as a “Highlight of 2018” by the editorial board of the leading European journal in medical physics (Physics in Medicine and Biology) and was featured on Medical Physics Web (now Physics World), the leading medical physics news and community website curated by the Institute of Physics.

The PI has also just received the 2021 Sanjay and Panna Mehrotra Research Excellence Award from the Health Applications Society of INFORMS, honoring in part this work on developing novel optimization methods and models for radiotherapy.
